[[Conspicuous Service Cross (Australia)|Conspicuous Service Cross]] |laterwork= }} [[Major General (Australia)|Major General]] '''Michael Simon "Mike" Hindmarsh''' [[Officer of the Order of Australia|AO]], [[Distinguished Service Cross (Australia)|DSC]], [[Conspicuous Service Cross (Australia)|CSC]] was a senior officer in the [[Australian Army]]. Hindmarsh served as [[Special Operations Command (Australia)|Special Operations Commander Australia]] from 2004 to 2008, and Commander of Australian Forces in the Middle East Area of Operations from March 2008 to January 2009. ==Military career== Mike Hindmarsh entered the [[Royal Military College, Duntroon]] in 1976, graduating into the [[Royal Australian Infantry Corps]] in 1978.[http://www.defence.gov.au/leaders/army/michaelHindmarsh/index.htm ADF Biography], retrieved 2008-09-26. He saw regimental service as a Platoon Commander with the [[2nd/4th Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment]] and as a Troop Commander, Squadron Commander and Commanding Officer with the [[Special Air Service Regiment]] (SASR). Other appointments included: SO3 Operations at HQ Land Command; SO2 Training at HQ UK Special Forces; SO1 Operations at HQ Special Forces; and Brigade level tactics instructor at the Land Warfare Centre. As Commanding Officer of the SASR, he commanded the ANZAC Special Operations Force detachment to Operation Pollard in [[Kuwait]] during 1998.[http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/honours/honour_roll/search.cfm?aus_award_id=914445&search_type=simple&showInd=true Conspicuous Service Cross], 14 June 1999, It's an honour.gov.au, Retrieved on 2009-09-09. Hindmarsh was later appointed to command the Special Operations Component on Operation Bastille and [[Australian contribution to the 2003 invasion of Iraq|Operation Falconer]] in the [[Iraq War]]. He was appointed as a [[Member of the Order of Australia]] for his distinguished leadership in this position.[http://www.ag.gov.au/portal/govgazonline.nsf/87F248FD00CFDFCCCA256DEB000CB8E6/$file/S423.pdf Commonwealth of Australia Gazette] - Member of the Order of Australia; 27 November 2003, page 1 He served as the [[Special Operations Command (Australia)|Australian Special Operations Commander]] from October 2004 to February 2008. He was appointed an [[Officer of the Order of Australia]] in the [[Australia Day Honours]] of 2008 for his distinguished service in that position.[http://www.ag.gov.au/portal/govgazonline.nsf/37A82594C117D9E1CA2573DB00497E37/$file/S%201.pdf Commonwealth of Australia Gazette] - Officer of the Order of Australia; 28 January 2008, page 3 - retrieved 2008-09-26. Hindmarsh assumed command of Australian Forces in the Middle East Area of Operations in an official ceremony on 1 March 2008; he succeeded [[Major General (Australia)|Major General]] [[Mark Evans (general)|Mark Evans]] in this position. His tour ended on 12 January 2009, at which time he was succeeded by Major General [[Mark Andrew Kelly]]. For his "distinguished command and leadership in action in the Middle East", Hindmarsh was awarded the [[Distinguished Service Cross (Australia)|Distinguished Service Cross]].{{cite web|url=http://www.gg.gov.au/res/File/PDFs/honours/qb09/Media%20Notes%20DSC%20(final).pdf|title=Distinguished Service Cross (DSC)|accessdate=8 June 2009|work=The Queen's Birthday 2009 Honours List|publisher=Governor-General of Australia}} From March 2009, Hindmarsh assumed command of Army Training Command at [[Victoria Barracks]], Sydney. ==Retirement== Hindmarsh retired from the Australian Army in later half of 2009.[http://www.rusiaust.org/states/wa/publications/Newsletter_WA_Sep09.pdf Newsletter], September 2009, Royal United Services Institute, Western Australian Branch. Retrieved on 2009-09-17. ==Personal== Hindmarsh is a graduate of the [[Army Command and Staff College, Queenscliff]], the [[Joint Services Command and Staff College]] and the United Kingdom [[Royal College of Defence Studies]]. He is married and has three sons.
